facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1961 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and decree dated July 17, 1958 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 162 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated July 17, 1958 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 162 of 1952.

facts.text: The suit was instituted by the appellant against the respondents for recovery of Rs. 57,000/-

anchor.surface_text: and arises out of a suit instituted by the appellant against the respondents for the recovery of a sum of Rs. 57,000/-

facts.text: Appellant holds permanent lease-hold rights over Jealgora Govindpur Colliery.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant holds permanent lease-hold rights over a colliery called the Jealgora Govindpur Colliery and had worked the colliery himself

facts.text: Appellant worked the colliery himself for some time.

anchor.surface_text: the colliery called the Jealgora Govindpur Colliery and had worked the colliery himself for some time.

facts.text: On January 31, 1949, appellant granted sub-lease of the colliery to respondent No. 4 for five years.

anchor.surface_text: On January 31, 1949, he granted a sub-lease of the colliery to respondent No. 4 for a term of five years.

facts.text: At the time of sub-lease, 2803 tons of slack and rubble coal was lying in the colliery.

anchor.surface_text: At that time, 2803 tons of slack and rubble coal was lying in the colliery, and under the terms of a separate agreement

facts.text: Appeal by certificate granted by Patna High Court under Art. 133(1)(a) of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by a certificate granted by the High Court of Patna under Art. 133 1  a  of the Constitution,

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 1, 1964 by Mudholkar J.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from that, s. 22 of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, clearly provides that in order to bind a firm by an act or an instrument executed by a partner on behalf of the firm, the act should be done or the instrument should be executed in the name of the firm, or in any other manner expressing or implying an intention to bind the firm.

concepts.interpretation: Requires act or instrument executed by partner to be in the name of the firm or otherwise express/imply intention to bind the firm; applied to hold firm not bound by sub-lease not executed in firm's name and without intention as found by lower courts.

issues.text: whether respondent No. 4 being a partner in the Saurashtra Coal Concern, all the partners of the firm are liable under the lease inasmuch as the firm admittedly came into possession of the demised colliery

anchor.surface_text: the only point urged by Mr. Sarjoo Prasad in support of the appeal is that respondent No. 4 being a partner in the Saurashtra Coal Concern, all the partners of the firm are liable under the lease inasmuch as the firm admittedly came into possession of the demised colliery. He points out that even according to respondents 1 to 3, they came into possession of the demised colliery immediately after the execution of the sub-lease, and wants this Court to infer from this that the partnership had already come into existence before the lease was obtained.

issues.text: whether it would be proper to permit the appellant to make out an entirely new case at this stage

anchor.surface_text: This, however, has never been the case of the appellant in the courts below. The only case which he put forward was that the lease was taken by respondent No. 4 on behalf of all the respondents. In other words, his case was that respondent No. 4 was a benamidar for the partnership firm. It is only this case which the respondents had to meet, and in our judgment, it would not be proper to permit the appellant to make out an entirely new case at this stage.

issues.text: whether the sub-lease binds the firm under s. 22 of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932

anchor.surface_text: Apart from that, s. 22 of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, clearly provides that in order to bind a firm by an act or an instrument executed by a partner on behalf of the firm, the act should be done or the instrument should be executed in the name of the firm, or in any other manner expressing or implying an intention to bind the firm. The sub-lease was not executed in the name of the firm, and it has been found by the courts below that respondent No. 4 in obtaining the lease, did not act on behalf of the firm.

issues.text: whether respondent No. 4 was a benamidar for the partnership firm making all respondents liable

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case was that respondent No. 4 was a benamidar for the partnership firm and, therefore, all the respondents were liable for the claim. Respondents 4 & 5, who are father and son, admitted the appellants contention that the lease was obtained by respondent No. 4 on behalf of the partnership firm, but their contention was that they surrendered their lease-hold interest to the appellant on November 1, 1950

issues.text: whether there was privity of contract between the appellant and respondents 1-3

anchor.surface_text: According to them, respondent No. 4 took the sub- lease in his personal capacity and not on behalf of the other respondents. They averred that there was no privity of contract between them and the appellant and that, therefore. he was not entitled to a decree against them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court defers to concurrent factual findings of lower courts regarding who took the sub-lease

holdings.text: it would not be proper to permit the appellant to make out an entirely new case at this stage
holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant previously relied only on benamidar theory which was met by respondents; new theory of pre-existing partnership not pleaded below

holdings.text: The sub-lease was not executed in the name of the firm, and it has been found by the courts below that respondent No. 4 in obtaining the lease, did not act on behalf of the firm
holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.22 requiring execution in firm name or clear intention to bind, neither satisfied per lower courts' findings

holdings.text: in obtaining the sub-lease, the parties to it did not intend to bind the firm by that transaction
holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance of lower courts' finding and s.22 application shows no intention to bind firm despite possession

precedents.citation: Karmali Abdulla Allarakia v. Vora Karimji Jiwanji and others 1

anchor.surface_text: Karmali Abdulla Allarakia v. Vora Karimji Jiwanji and others 1 . That was a case in which the question for companysideration was whether one of the two partners is liable upon a hundi drawn by one of the partners though the hundi was number drawn in the name of the firm.

precedents.case_name: Karmali Abdulla Allarakia v Vora Karimji Jiwanji
precedents.cited_proposition: whether one of the two partners is liable upon a hundi drawn by one of the partners though the hundi was not drawn in the name of the firm
precedents.cited_holding: the other partner would be liable though on the face of it the hundi did not purport to be on behalf of the firm

anchor.surface_text: Gouthwaite v. Duckworth 1  held that the other partner would be liable though on the face of it the hundi did number purport to be on behalf of the firm. That decision, however, does number help the appellant, because while the transaction in companynection

precedents.cited_proposition: partner liable on instrument not in firm name if partnership transaction
precedents.cited_holding: the other partner would be liable though on the face of it the hundi did not purport to be on behalf of the firm

precedents.citation: Mathura Nath Choudhury v. Sreejukta Bageswari Rani and others 2

anchor.surface_text: Mathura Nath Choudhury v. Sreejukta Bageswari Rani and others 2 . In that case, the question was whether the firm is liable for the money borrowed by one of its partners. The High Court pointed out that this is a question of fact and depends upon the facts and circumstances of each particular case.

precedents.case_name: Mathura Nath Choudhury v Sreejukta Bageswari Rani
precedents.cited_proposition: firm liable for money borrowed by partner
precedents.cited_holding: liability arises upon a contract entered into by one of the partners in connection with the partnership business

anchor.surface_text: Pandiri Veeranna v. Grandi Veerabhadraswami 4 . In that case, the question was whether the fact that one of the several partners had authority to acknowlede liability to save limitation as against his partners, had to be established only by direct evidence or whether it companyld be inferred

precedents.cited_proposition: authority of partner to acknowledge liability can be inferred from circumstances
precedents.cited_holding: permissible to establish the existence of authority from the surrounding circumstances

precedents.citation: Lakshmishankar Devshankar v. Motiram Vishnuram, etc. 1

anchor.surface_text: Lakshmishankar Devshankar v. Motiram Vishnuram, etc. 1 . There, it was held that where money borrowed by one partner in the name of the firm but without the authority of the company partners has been applied to paying off the debts of the firm, the lender is entitled in equity to repayment

precedents.cited_proposition: firm liable for borrowing by partner used for firm purposes even without authority
precedents.cited_holding: where money borrowed by one partner in the name of the firm but without the authority of the other partners has been applied to paying off the debts of the firm, the lender is entitled in equity to repayment by the firm
